It provides several benefits for patients, including the ability to preserve fertility for later use, a backup option for unused embryos, and cost-effectiveness. If you are considering preserving your fertility, it is important to discuss your options with a fertility specialist to determine if embryo freezing is right for you.

desc.title: Why freeze embryos?
fdesc: Embryos can be frozen to allow couples to preserve their fertility for later use, such as if they are undergoing cancer treatment or waiting to start a family.

desc.title: How long can embryos be frozen?
fdesc: Embryos can be stored for many years and still remain viable for future use.

desc.title: What are the success rates of embryo thawing and transfer?
fdesc: The success rates of embryo thawing and transfer can vary, but studies have shown that the success rates are similar to those of fresh embryos. The success of the procedure depends on many factors, including the age of the woman, the quality of the embryos, and the reason for freezing.

treatment_desc: Laparoscopy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure that involves the use of a laparoscope - a thin, lighted tube with a camera attached - to view the inside of the abdominal and pelvic cavities. The procedure is performed through small incisions in the abdominal wall, allowing the doctor to diagnose and treat various conditions affecting the reproductive organs, such as infertility, endometriosis, and fibroids.

desc: Laparoscopy is performed to diagnose and treat various conditions affecting the reproductive organs, such as:
Infertility
Endometriosis
Ovarian cysts
Ectopic pregnancy
Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
Fibroids
Tubal ligation (female sterilization)
Laparoscopy offers several benefits compared to traditional open surgery, including:
Minimal scarring
Reduced pain and discomfort
Quicker recovery time
Less risk of complications
The steps involved in a laparoscopy procedure include:
The patient is given general or regional anesthesia.
Insertion of Laparoscope: The laparoscope is inserted through a small incision in the abdominal wall, allowing the doctor to view the inside of the abdominal cavity.

Diagnosis and Treatment: Depending on the condition being treated, the doctor may perform various diagnostic and treatment procedures, such as biopsy, removal of cysts, or removal of endometrial tissue.
Closing Incisions: The small incisions are closed with sutures or staples.

Most patients are able to return to their normal activities within a few days of the procedure, although the exact recovery time will depend on the extent of the procedure and the patient's overall health. It is important to follow the doctor's instructions for post-operative care to ensure a quick and healthy recovery.

desc.title: What conditions can Laparoscopy treat?
fdesc: Laparoscopy can be used to treat a variety of conditions, including endometriosis, fibroids, ovarian cysts, and pelvic pain.

desc.title: Is Laparoscopy safe?
fdesc: Laparoscopy is generally considered a safe procedure, but like any surgery, there are risks involved such as infection, bleeding, and damage to internal organs. Your doctor will be able to discuss the risks and benefits with you.

desc.title: What conditions can Laparoscopy treat?
fdesc: Laparoscopy can be used to treat a variety of conditions, including endometriosis, fibroids, ovarian cysts, and pelvic pain.

treatment_desc: Hysteroscopy is a diagnostic procedure that allows a doctor to examine the inside of the uterus. It involves the insertion of a hysteroscope, a thin and lighted tube, through the vagina and cervix into the uterus. This procedure is used to identify the causes of various gynecological problems such as abnormal bleeding, infertility, and abnormal growths.

desc: The main purpose of hysteroscopy is to diagnose and treat various uterine conditions. Some of the common conditions that can be diagnosed and treated through this procedure are:
Abnormal uterine bleeding: Hysteroscopy can help identify the cause of abnormal bleeding, such as uterine fibroids, polyps, or adhesions.
Hysteroscopy can help identify and treat any structural abnormalities in the uterus that may be causing infertility.
Abnormal growths: Hysteroscopy can help identify and remove uterine fibroids, polyps, or adhesions.
Before the procedure, your doctor will give you specific instructions on how to prepare. This may include:
Avoiding food and drink for several hours before the procedure
Taking medications as directed by your doctor
Notifying your doctor of any allergies or medical conditions

During the hysteroscopy procedure, the doctor will insert the hysteroscope through the vagina and cervix into the uterus. A saline solution may be used to expand the uterus and allow for better visualization. The doctor will then examine the inside of the uterus using the hysteroscope. If necessary, the doctor may also perform biopsy or remove any growths.

After the procedure, you will be monitored for a short period of time. You may experience some cramping and light bleeding, but these symptoms should resolve within a few days. Your doctor will give you specific instructions on when you can return to your normal activities and when you should follow up for your next appointment.

desc.title: is Hysteroscopy safe?
fdesc: Hysteroscopy is a safe and effective diagnostic procedure that helps doctors diagnose and treat various gynecological conditions. If you have any questions or concerns about this procedure, be sure to talk to your doctor.

desc.title: Why is Uterine Septal Resection performed?
fdesc: The procedure is performed to treat uterine malformations, such as a septate uterus, which can cause fertility problems, recurrent miscarriages, or problems during pregnancy.

desc.title: What is the recovery time for Uterine Septal Resection?
fdesc: ecovery time can vary, but most patients can return to normal activities within 1-2 weeks.

treatment_desc: Uterine septal resection, also known as hysteroscopic septum resection, is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat a uterine septum. A uterine septum is a partition of tissue within the uterus that can cause infertility, recurrent miscarriages, or abnormal uterine bleeding.

desc: he purpose of uterine septal resection is to remove the partition of tissue within the uterus and restore the normal shape of the uterus. This can help to improve fertility and reduce the risk of recurrent miscarriages. It can also relieve symptoms of abnormal uterine bleeding.
Before the procedure, your doctor will give you specific instructions on how to prepare. This may include:
Avoiding food and drink for several hours before the procedure
Taking medications as directed by your doctor
Notifying your doctor of any allergies or medical conditions

During the uterine septal resection procedure, the doctor will insert a hysteroscope, a thin and lighted tube, through the vagina and cervix into the uterus. A saline solution may be used to expand the uterus and allow for better visualization. The doctor will then use special instruments to remove the partition of tissue within the uterus.

After the procedure, you will be monitored for a short period of time. You may experience some cramping and light bleeding, but these symptoms should resolve within a few days. Your doctor will give you specific instructions on when you can return to your normal activities and when you should follow up for your next appointment.

desc.title: Why is USR performed?
fdesc: USR is performed to treat infertility and recurrent pregnancy loss caused by a uterine septum.

desc.title: What are the risks and side effects of USR?
fdesc: Like all surgical procedures, USR carries a risk of bleeding, infection, and scarring. Additionally, there may be temporary side effects such as cramping and spotting after the procedure.

treatment_desc: Myomectomy is a surgical procedure performed to remove uterine fibroids, which are noncancerous growths that can cause discomfort and infertility. There are several methods available to treat fibroids, and the best one for you will depend on the size, location, and number of fibroids, as well as your personal health and reproductive goals.

desc: 1. Laparoscopic Myomectomy
This minimally invasive procedure is performed through small incisions in the abdomen, using a laparoscope to visualize the uterus and remove fibroids.
2. Abdominal Myomectomy
This traditional open surgery is performed through a larger incision in the abdomen and is typically recommended for larger or multiple fibroids.
3. Hysteroscopic Myomectomy

This procedure is performed through the vagina and cervix using a hysteroscope, a thin instrument with a light attached. It is only appropriate for fibroids that are located within the uterus and can be reached through the cervix.
1. Relief from Symptoms: Myomectomy can provide relief from symptoms such as heavy menstrual bleeding, pain, and pressure.
2. Fertility Preservation: Myomectomy can help preserve fertility for women who wish to become pregnant in the future.
3. Improved Quality of Life: By removing fibroids and improving symptoms, myomectomy can significantly improve a woman's quality of life.

As with any surgery, myomectomy carries certain risks and potential complications, including bleeding, infection, and damage to surrounding organs. However, the risk of these complications is low and depends on the type of myomectomy performed and the patient's overall health.

It is important to discuss all potential risks and benefits of myomectomy with your doctor to determine if it is the right treatment option for you. Your doctor can also recommend lifestyle changes and medications to manage fibroids and minimize the need for surgery.

desc.title: What are the symptoms of uterine fibroids?
fdesc: Common symptoms of uterine fibroids include heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain or pressure, frequent urination, constipation and lower back pain.

desc.title: What is the purpose of Myomectomy?
fdesc: The purpose of Myomectomy is to remove uterine fibroids and preserve the uterus, allowing women to have children in the future if they so desire.

desc.title: Is Myomectomy a permanent solution for uterine fibroids?
fdesc: Myomectomy can be an effective treatment for uterine fibroids, but it is not a guarantee that they will not grow back. Regular follow-up and monitoring is recommended to ensure the best outcomes.

treatment_desc: Endometrial/ Dermoid cysts are growths that develop in the ovaries and are typically benign, however, in some cases, they can become cancerous or lead to other health issues. A cystectomy is a surgical procedure that involves removing the cyst from the ovary. This procedure is performed through laparoscopy or open surgery and can be done as an outpatient procedure.

desc: Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy is typically performed when cysts are causing symptoms, such as abdominal pain, bloating, and menstrual irregularities, or if they are found to be suspicious on ultrasound or other imaging tests.

sub_data.sub-title: What are the benefits of Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy?
desc: Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy can alleviate symptoms caused by cysts and reduce the risk of complications such as torsion (twisting of the cyst), rupture, and malignancy. The procedure can also help to preserve fertility by removing the cysts and leaving the ovaries intact.

Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy is typically performed using minimally invasive techniques, such as laparoscopy, which involves making small incisions and using a camera to visualize the ovaries and remove the cysts.

sub_data.sub-title: What is the recovery process like after Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy?
desc: The recovery process following Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy typically involves a few days of rest and a gradual return to normal activities. Pain, swelling, and bloating are common after the procedure, but can be managed with medication. Most women can return to work within a week and resume normal activities within several weeks.

desc.title: Is Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy effective?
fdesc: Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy is generally considered to be an effective treatment for endometrial and dermoid cysts, providing relief from symptoms and reducing the risk of complications. The success of the procedure depends on various factors, including the size and location of the cysts and the overall health of the patient.

desc.title: Is Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy safe?
fdesc: Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy is a safe and effective treatment option for women with endometrial or dermoid cysts that are causing symptoms or are suspicious on imaging tests.

faqpage.title: What is the PGT procedure?
fdesc: The three different PGTs are all carried out similarly. The patient follows the doctor's advice and has an IVF cycle and egg retrieval. Their embryos are observed in our lab till they are referred to as blastocysts on day 5 or day 6. A few cells are extracted from the biopsyed (removed) embryos and sent to a lab for PGT. The blastocyst's trophectoderm eventually develops into the placenta.

It is anticipated that these cells will constitute the remainder of the embryo, although due to things like mosaicism, this may not always be the case (see question 13). The embryo(s) must be frozen before PGT. An embryo with normal PGT results will be chosen, frozen, and implanted into the patient's uterus later.

faqpage.title: When must I decide whether to pursue PGT?
fdesc: You should decide to have PGT a long time before your IVF cycle. Before an IVF cycle can occur, DNA samples from the patient, their partner or donor, and occasionally other family members, may need to be obtained.

To see if the lab will be able to accurately identify the genetic alterations in the patient's embryo, PGT-M is put through a test development phase. The test creation stage can take up to 12 weeks after receiving all DNA samples. This procedure must be finished in its entirety before an IVF cycle (stimulating drugs) can begin.

faqpage.title: The PGT-A test looks for what kinds of chromosomal abnormalities?
fdesc: The main goal of a PGT-A embryo is to guarantee that it is euploid, or having the appropriate amount of chromosomes. PGT-A can identify monosomies (incomplete chromosomes) and trisomies (incomplete chromosomes) in embryos. PGT-A also checks for chromosomal duplications and deletions. Large deletions and duplications are necessary for their detection. In some versions, but not all, the PGT-A may also pick up on mosaicism and uniparental disomy (UPD). Our genetic counsellor will go over the different kinds of outcomes that can be discovered during your session.

faqpage.title: Why Is It Performed?
fdesc: Pregnancy rates are greater after blastocyst-stage embryo transfer on the fifth day. There are potentially two plausible explanations for this:
In the beginning, transferring the blastocyst to the uterus may be more medically suitable because it closely mimics nature, increasing the likelihood that the embryo will implant.
Furthermore, waiting until the blastocyst stage allows the expert to select the best embryo because undesired babies are likely to terminate before they get to this stage.

faqpage.title: Who ought to use IVF and assisted hatching?
fdesc: Some couples with a poor prognosis may benefit from assisted hatching since their embryos may not have the energy to finish the hatching process.
According to the American Society for Reproductive Medicine, women with the following conditions may benefit from assisted hatching:
Mother's advanced age (older than 38) Two or more IVF cycles that failed A bad quality embryo

Fundamentally, the likelihood of potentially hazardous twin or triplet birth is reduced by blastocyst transfer. Higher implantation rates allow doctors to exchange fewer blastocysts, possibly just one, reducing or avoiding multiple births and the problems they bring. With the help of vitrification, extra blastocysts can also be successfully cryopreserved so that pregnancies can be carried out in the future.

faqpage.title: Advantages of the blastocyst method over traditional embryo transfer techniques
fdesc: The majority of embryo transfers in the past took place on days two or three. In any event, the majority of excellent clinics have moved on to routinely performing day five (blastocyst) transfers. Tragically, many IVF clinics in India still transfer embryos on the second or third day because this is not yet the common option. This is primarily due to their lack of tremendous confidence in the capabilities of their research facility and their embryologist's ability to culture eggs up to day five. They justify this by telling the patient that it's preferable for the embryo to hatch inside the uterus earlier, which is why they lean toward transferring the embryo into the uterus. However, there are a lot of disadvantages to this, therefore you should request that your doctor perform a blastocyst transfer on your behalf.

When compared to Day 2 or Day 3 transfer, blastocysts have a higher possibility of implanting, hence the success percentage is higher with blastocyst transfer. They are more  likely since they are more developed and have more cells. When compared to transferring three or four Day 3 embryos, the specialist can reduce the number of embryos to be transferred and exchange only a few blastocysts while still having a high pregnancy rate.

Additionally, since the expert is only exchanging 1–2 blastocysts, you can freeze the extra blastocysts, giving you the chance to complete multiple cycles in the future. In light of the fact that the overall pregnancy rate is increasing, this makes it more useful.

The final and most important reason to request a blastocyst transfer is that you won't have to endure the scary 2-week wait during which you won't know whether you will become pregnant or not if you have poor quality embryos. Therefore, if the IVF cycle fails after exchanging Day 3 embryos, it is impossible to determine if the problem was that the foetus did not develop further or whether there was some other reason why the implantation failed. Even more so, you're uncertain as to whether your embryo will live for five days or not.

This is especially true for older women with fewer eggs. Such women are more likely to experience a failed IVF because their embryos are more likely to halt and not develop into blastocysts. Many of the embryos can be genetically abnormal.

These are the patients who might benefit most greatly from a blastocyst transfer. However, because they typically have poor ovarian response, the doctor is reluctant to develop the embryos all the way to the blastocyst stage when just 3–4 eggs are collected. The patient will blame them if it doesn't work out. For this reason, they would much rather transfer the embryos back into the uterus, where they could claim "implantation failure" if the cycle did not succeed.

However, following the embryo swap, the patient is duped into believing that "Amazingly, possibly this embryo may implant and grow into a baby," which is why they are so optimistic during the waiting period.

This false expectation is hurting. They believe that their uterus rejected the embryo at the time when the cycle ends prematurely, which is when they are persuaded to pursue surrogacy. This is dreadful advise which is absolutely imperfect on the grounds that the issue is with the egg and not with the uterus.

Aveya IVF maintains an honest approach with all the patients and gives the best potential outcome in each situation. This is combined with our highly skilled and informed specialists who can assist you in getting the greatest outcome from your IVF operation. Consult with our skilled fertility doctors to know more about this process and discuss your alternatives.

faqpage.title: What does egg donation entail?
fdesc: When a woman gives her eggs (or oocytes), she is assisting another woman in getting pregnant. The male partner's sperm or donor sperm may be used to fertilise donor eggs.

If there are no medical reasons why a woman shouldn't carry a pregnancy, donor egg IVF may be a viable choice for those who are unable to conceive with their own eggs. Advanced age, a decreased ovarian reserve, early ovarian failure that is either undiagnosed or brought on by autoimmune diseases, chemotherapy, or surgical menopause are all indications for donor egg IVF. IVF with donor eggs is also suitable for women who have genetic mutations.

faqpage.title: The egg donation procedure
fdesc: According to ICMR rules, egg donation is a private practise. Donors of eggs are typically young, healthy women with one or more kids. Infections like HIV and hepatitis are screened for, and a full medical and psychological evaluation is also performed. The ICMR's recommended tests are carried out, and its rules are properly adhered to. An egg donor will be added to the programme once the application and legal documents have been finished.

faqpage.title: How is donor egg IVF carried out?
fdesc: IVF donor egg cycles mix the recipient and donor egg cycles. The menstrual cycle of the egg donor and the recipient's use of birth control tablets are often coordinated. On the second day of menstruation, the receiver starts taking estradiol tablets to prepare her uterus, while the donor starts receiving injections to stimulate her ovaries. Once the donor's follicles are prepared, which typically takes 11–12 days, the egg retrieval operation is carried out under anaesthetic and ultrasound monitoring. The recipient's partner gives a sample of his semen on the day of egg retrieval. The gametes are then fertilised in a laboratory setting. The recipient is given luteal support medicines. Three to five days later, a USG directs the transfer of one to two embryos into the recipient's uterus. If there are extra embryos, they can be stored in the freezer for later use.

faqpage.title: What is azoospermia?
fdesc: Azoospermia is a condition in which there’s no measurable sperm in a man’s ejaculate (semen). Azoospermia leads to male infertility.

faqpage.title: How common is azoospermia?
fdesc: About 1% of all men and 10% to 15% of infertile men have azoospermia.

faqpage.title: What are the parts of the male reproductive system?
fdesc: The male reproductive system is made up of the following:
Testes, or testicles produce sperm (male reproductive cells) in a process called spermatogenesis.
Seminiferous tubules are tiny tubes that make up most of the tissue of the testes.
Epididymis is the structure on the back of each testicle into which mature  sperm are moved and stored.
It is the muscular tube that passes from the epididymis into the pelvis then curves around and enters the seminal vesicle.
Seminal vesicle is a tubular gland that produces and stores most of the fluid ingredients of semen. The vesicle narrows to form a straight duct, the seminal duct, which joins with the vas deferens
Ejaculatory duct is created when the seminal vesicle duct merges with the vas deferens. The ejaculatory duct passes into the prostate gland and connects with the urethra.
Urethra is the tube that runs through the penis to eliminate urine from the bladder and semen from the vas deferens.

During ejaculation, sperm move from the testes and the epididymis into the vas deferens. Tightening (contraction) of the vas deferens moves the sperm along. Secretions from the seminal vesicle are added and the seminal fluid continues to move forward toward the urethra. Before reaching the urethra, the seminal fluid passes by the prostate gland, which adds a milky fluid to the sperm to form semen. Lastly, the semen is ejaculated (released) through the penis through the urethra. </br></br>A normal sperm count is considered to be 15 million/mL or more. Men with low sperm counts (oligozoospermia or oligospermia) have a sperm concentration of less than 15 million/mL. If you have azoospermia, you have no measurable sperm in your ejaculate.

faqpage.title: Are there different types of azoospermia?
fdesc: There are two main types of azoospermia:

Obstructive azoospermia: This type of azoospermia means that there is a blockage or missing connection in the epididymis, vas deferens, or elsewhere along your reproductive tract. You are producing sperm but it’s getting blocked from exit so there’s no measurable amount of sperm in your semen.
Nonobstructive azoospermia: This type of azoospermia means you have poor or no sperm production due to defects in the structure or function of the testicles or other causes.

faqpage.title: What are the causes of azoospermia?
fdesc: The causes of azoospermia relate directly to the types of azoospermia. In other words, causes can be due to an obstruction or nonobstructive sources.
Obstructions that result in azoospermia most commonly occur in the vas deferens, the epididymus or ejaculatory ducts. Problems that can cause blockages in these areas include:
1. Trauma or injury to these areas.
2. Infections.
3. Inflammation.
4. Previous surgeries in the pelvic area.
5. Development of a cyst.
6. Vasectomy (planned permanent contraceptive procedure in which the vas deferens are cut or clamped to prevent the flow of sperm).
7. Cystic fibrosis gene mutation, which causes either the vas deferens not to form or causes abnormal development such that semen gets blocked by a buildup of thick secretions in the vas deferens.
Nonobstructive causes of azoospermia include:
Genetic causes. Certain genetic mutations can result in infertility, including:
a.Kallmann syndrome: A genetic (inherited) disorder carried on the X chromosome and that if left untreated can result in infertility.

b.Klinefelter’s syndrome: A male carries an extra X chromosome (making his chromosomal makeup XXY instead of XY). The result is often infertility, along with lack of sexual or physical maturity, and learning difficulties.
c.Y chromosome deletion: Critical sections of genes on the Y chromosome (the male chromosome) that are responsible for sperm production are missing, resulting in infertility.
8. Hormone imbalances/endocrine disorders, including hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. hyperprolactinemia and androgen resistance.
9. Ejaculation problems such as retrograde ejaculation where the semen goes in to the bladder
10. Testicular causes include:
a.Anorchia (absence of the testicles).
b.Cyptorchidism (testicles have not dropped into the scrotum).
c.Sertoli cell-only syndrome (testicles fail to produce living sperm cells).
d.Spermatogenic arrest (testicles fail to produce fully mature sperm cells).
e.Mumps orchitis (inflamed testicles caused by mumps in late puberty).
f.Testicular torsion.
g.Tumors.
h.Reactions to certain medications that harm sperm production.
i.Radiation treatments.
j.Diseases such as diabetes, cirrhosis, or kidney failure.
k. Varicocele (veins coming from the testicle are dilated or widened impeding sperm production).

faqpage.title: How is azoospermia diagnosed?
fdesc: Azoospermia is diagnosed when, on two separate occasions, your sperm sample reveals no sperm when examined under a high-powered microscope following a spin in a centrifuge. A centrifuge is a laboratory instrument that spins a test sample at a high speed to separate it into its various parts. In the case of centrifuged seminal fluid, if sperm cells are present, they separate from the fluid around them and can be viewed under a microscope.
As part of the diagnosis, your healthcare provider will take your medical history, including asking you about the following:
1. Fertility success or failure in the past (your ability to have children).
2. Childhood illnesses.
3. Injuries or surgeries in the pelvic area (these could cause duct blockage or poor blood supply to the testicles).
4. Urinary or reproductive tract infections.
5. History of sexually transmitted diseases.
6. Exposure to radiation or chemotherapy.
7. Your current and past medications.
8. Any abuse of alcohol, marijuana or other drugs.
9. Recent fevers or exposure to heat, including frequent saunas or steam baths (heat kills sperm cells).
10. Family history of birth defects, learning disabilities, reproductive failure or cystic fibrosis.
Your healthcare provider will also conduct a physical examination, and will check:
11. Your entire body in terms of signs of/lack of maturation of your body and reproductive organs.

12. Your penis and scrotum, checking for the presence of your vas deferens, tenderness or swelling of your epididymis, size of the testicles, the presence or absence of a varicocele, and any blockage of the ejaculatory duct (via exam through the rectum) as evidenced by enlarged seminal vesicles.
Your healthcare provider may also order the following tests:
13. Measurement of testosterone and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels.
14. Genetic testing.
15.X-rays or ultrasound of the reproductive organs to see if there are any problems with the shape and size, and to see if there are tumors, blockages or an inadequate blood supply.
16. Imaging of the brain to identify disorders of the hypothalamus or pituitary gland.

17. Biopsy (tissue sampling) of the testes. A normal biopsy would mean a blockage is probable at some point in the sperm transport system. Sometimes, any sperm found in the testes is frozen for future analysis or can be used in assisted pregnancy.

faqpage.title: How is azoospermia treated?
fdesc: Treatment of azoospermia depends on the cause. Genetic testing and counselling are often an important part of understanding and treating azoospermia. Treatment approaches include:
If a blockage is the cause of your azoospermia, surgery can unblock tubes or reconstruct and connect abnormal or never developed tubes.

If low hormone production is the main cause, you may be given hormone treatments. Hormones include follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG), clomiphene, anastrazole and letrozole.
If a varicocele is the cause of poor sperm production, the problem veins can be tied off in a surgical procedure, keeping surrounding structures preserved.
Sperm can be retrieved directly from the testicle with an extensive biopsy in some men

If living sperm are present, they can be retrieved from the testes, epididymis or vas deferens for assisted pregnancy procedures such as in vitro fertilization or intracytoplasmic sperm injection (the injection of one sperm into one egg). If the cause of azoospermia is thought to be something that could be passed on to children, your healthcare provider may recommend genetic analysis of your sperm before assisted fertilization procedures are considered.

faqpage.title: How can azoospermia be prevented?
fdesc: There is no known way to prevent the genetic problems that cause azoospermia. If your azoospermia is not a genetic problem, doing the following can help lessen the chance of azoospermia:
1. Avoid activities that could injure the reproductive organs.
2. Avoid exposure to radiation.
3. Know the risks and benefits of medications that could harm sperm production.
4. Avoid lengthy exposure of your testes to hot temperatures.

faqpage.title: What is the long-term outlook for those with azoospermia?
fdesc: Every cause of azoospermia has a different prognosis. Many causes of azoospermia can be reversed. You and your healthcare team will work together to determine the cause of your azoospermia and treatment options. Hormonal problems and obstructive causes of azoospermia are usually treatable and fertility can potentially be restored. If testicular disorders are the cause, it’s still possible to retrieve live sperm to be used in assisted reproductive techniques.

faqpage.title: How is recurrent miscarriage diagnosed?
fdesc: Diagnosis of recurrent miscarriage typically involves a thorough evaluation of the individual's medical history, a physical examination, and various diagnostic tests, such as an ultrasound, blood tests, and genetic testing.

faqpage.title: Can recurrent miscarriage be prevented?
fdesc: Preventing recurrent miscarriage is not always possible, but making lifestyle changes, such as quitting smoking, maintaining a healthy weight, and managing stress, may help reduce the risk of recurrent miscarriage. Seeking prompt and thorough evaluation and treatment for any underlying causes is also important.

faqpage.title: Does polycystic ovary syndrome run in families?
fdesc: The reasons of PCOS are still the subject of extensive research. Evidence suggests that PCOS has a genetic or inherited component, nevertheless.

faqpage.title: Can someone with PCOS become pregnant?
fdesc: If you have PCOS, you can still become pregnant. PCOS can make it difficult to get pregnant and raise your risk for some pregnancy issues. Together with you, your healthcare physician will create a treatment strategy to assist you in ovulating. You could use medicine or assisted reproductive methods like IVF as part of your treatment plan (In Vitro Fertilization).
To make sure you comprehend your treatment plan and how to improve your chances of a safe and successful pregnancy, speak with your healthcare practitioner.

faqpage.title: What hormones are impacted by PCOS?
fdesc: A hormonal imbalance in women with PCOS causes disruptions in the menstrual cycle, ovulation, and maybe pregnancy. The balance of these hormones, which form a complicated web, is crucial for the female reproductive system to work properly. The following hormones are involved in PCOS:
Androgens (such testosterone and androstenedione) (like testosterone and androstenedione).
Vitamin D hormone (LH).
FSH stands for folicle-stimulating hormone.
Estroge Progesterone.
Insulin.

faqpage.title: What distinguishes PCOS from endometriosis?
fdesc: Despite being distinct diseases, ovarian cysts and infertility are associated with both PCOS and endometriosis. When you have endometriosis, the lining of your uterus (endometrium) begins to grow in other locations, such as your ovaries, vagina, or fallopian tubes. Usually, it results in severe menstrual cramps or pelvic pain. Due to an excess of male hormones, women with PCOS experience irregular periods, unexpected ovulation, and other physical side effects.

Infertility is frequently brought on by PCOS, which has been related to other illnesses. If you think you might have PCOS, discuss your symptoms with your doctor. You can control the symptoms, reduce your risk of developing additional health concerns, and get pregnant with the support of lifestyle modifications and medication therapies.

faqpage.title: How are endometriosis and adenomyosis diagnosed?
fdesc: Diagnosis of endometriosis and adenomyosis is typically made through a combination of a thorough medical history, physical examination, and imaging tests such as ultrasound or MRI.

faqpage.title: What is the treatment for endometriosis and adenomyosis?
fdesc: Treatment for endometriosis and adenomyosis may include pain management, hormonal therapy, surgery, or a combination of these approaches. The best course of treatment will depend on the individual's symptoms and the severity of the condition.

faqpage.title: What is the success rate of ICSI?
fdesc: The success rate of ICSI varies depending on a variety of factors such as the woman's age, the cause of infertility, and the quality of the sperm and eggs. On average, the success rate of ICSI is around 40-50%.

faqpage.title: Who is a candidate for ICSI?
fdesc: Couples who have failed to conceive with traditional in vitro fertilization (IVF) or have issues with sperm quality or quantity may be candidates for ICSI.

faqpage.title: Are there any risks or side effects associated with ICSI?
fdesc: As with any medical procedure, there are potential risks and side effects associated with ICSI. Some common side effects include ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS), multiple pregnancies, and a small risk of birth defects.

faqpage.title: What is PGT and how does it work?
fdesc: Preimplantation Genetic Testing (PGT) is a type of genetic screening performed during assisted reproductive technology (ART) treatments such as in vitro fertilization (IVF). It is used to detect any genetic or chromosomal abnormalities in embryos before they are implanted into the uterus.

faqpage.title: Who is a candidate for PGT?
fdesc: PGT is recommended for couples who have a history of genetic disorders, older women, or those who have experienced recurrent miscarriages. It can increase the chances of having a healthy baby, reduce the risk of miscarriage, and minimize the chance of passing on genetic disorders to the child.

faqpage.title: Is Ovation PRP safe?
fdesc: Ovation PRP is considered a safe and effective treatment for hair loss. The procedure uses a patient's own blood, so there is no risk of rejection or reaction. The treatment has been used for many years in various medical fields and has a proven track record of safety and effectiveness.

faqpage.title: How many Ovation PRP treatments are needed for optimal results?
fdesc: The number of Ovation PRP treatments needed for optimal results can vary from patient to patient. Typically, a series of 3-5 treatments are recommended, with each treatment spaced 4-6 weeks apart. After the initial series of treatments, maintenance treatments may be needed every 6-12 months to maintain the results. The exact number of treatments needed will depend on the individual's specific hair loss condition and their desired results.Regenerate response

faqpage.title: How is Endometrial PRP performed?
fdesc: Endometrial PRP is performed by drawing a small sample of the patient's blood and then processing it to concentrate the platelets. The concentrated platelets are then inserted into the uterus through a small catheter. The procedure is typically performed in a medical office and takes 30 minutes to an hour.

faqpage.title: What conditions does Endometrial PRP?
fdesc: Endometrial PRP has been used to treat a variety of conditions related to the endometrium, including thin endometrial lining, poor endometrial growth, and repeated implantation failures. The treatment has shown to be effective in promoting endometrial growth and increasing the chances of successful implantation and pregnancy. It is important to note that Endometrial PRP is not a guarantee for pregnancy and the results may vary from patient to patient.

faqpage.title: How is Testicular PRP performed?
fdesc: Testicular PRP is performed by drawing a small sample of the patient's blood and processing it to concentrate the platelets. The concentrated platelets are then injected into the testicles using a fine needle. The procedure is performed in a medical office and typically takes 30 minutes to an hour.

faqpage.title: What conditions does Testicular PRP treat?
fdesc: Testicular PRP has been used to treat a variety of conditions related to the testicles, including low sperm count, poor sperm quality, and testicular atrophy. The treatment has shown to be effective in improving testicular function and increasing sperm count and quality. It is important to note that Testicular PRP is not a guarantee for pregnancy and the results may vary from patient to patient. It is recommended to seek the advice of a medical professional for an evaluation and personalized treatment plan.

faqpage.title: How is PGT-SR performed?
fdesc: PGT-SR is performed by taking a sample of cells from the blastomeres (cells in the early-stage embryo) and analyzing them for the presence of structural chromosomal rearrangements. This can be done through a variety of methods, including fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), comparative genomic hybridization (CGH), and next-generation sequencing (NGS).

faqpage.title: What are the benefits of PGT-SR?
fdesc: The benefits of PGT-SR include the ability to identify embryos that are likely to lead to a successful pregnancy and reduce the risk of chromosomal disorders in the child. It can also increase the chances of having a healthy baby by selecting only genetically normal embryos for transfer to the uterus. PGT-SR can also help to reduce the number of unsuccessful IVF cycles and minimize the emotional stress associated with repeated failed attempts at pregnancy.

faqpage.title: How is PGT-M performed?
fdesc: PGT-M is performed by taking a sample of cells from the blastomeres (cells in the early-stage embryo) and analyzing them for the presence of specific mutations or variations in the genes of interest. This can be done through a variety of methods, including polymerase chain reaction (PCR), sequencing, and next-generation sequencing (NGS).

faqpage.title: What are the benefits of PGT-M?
fdesc: The benefits of PGT-M include the ability to identify embryos that are free of the specific genetic mutations or variations associated with monogenic disorders, increasing the chances of a successful pregnancy and the birth of a healthy baby. PGT-M can also reduce the risk of passing on genetic disorders to the child and minimize the emotional stress associated with the uncertainty of whether a genetic disorder will be present in the child. Additionally, by only transferring genetically normal embryos to the uterus, PGT-M can also help to reduce the number of unsuccessful IVF cycles.

faqpage.title: How is Chromosomal Karyotyping performed?
fdesc: Chromosomal Karyotyping is performed by taking cells, such as blood or skin cells, from the patient. The cells are then grown in a laboratory and treated with chemicals that make the chromosomes visible under a microscope. The chromosomes are then photographed and analyzed to identify any abnormalities.

faqpage.title: What are the benefits of Chromosomal Karyotyping?
fdesc: The benefits of Chromosomal Karyotyping include the ability to diagnose genetic disorders, understand the cause of infertility and miscarriage, and make informed decisions about treatment. This information can provide peace of mind for couples who are looking to start a family.

faqpage.title: Who should consider sperm aneuploidy screening?
fdesc: Sperm aneuploidy screening may be recommended for couples who are planning to have children and have a history of infertility, repeated failed IVF cycles, or a family history of chromosomal disorders. It may also be recommended for couples who are older or have a higher risk of having a baby with a chromosomal disorder due to advanced maternal age.

faqpage.title: How is sperm aneuploidy screening performed?
fdesc: Sperm aneuploidy screening is typically performed by analyzing a sample of sperm for the presence of abnormal chromosomes. This can be done through a variety of methods, including fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), comparative genomic hybridization (CGH), and next-generation sequencing (NGS).

faqpage.title: What is endometrial microbiota analysis?
fdesc: A test to assess the microbiome of the endometrium (uterine lining).

faqpage.title: How do I decide whether to be tested?
fdesc: There are many reasons that people might get genetic testing. Doctors might suggest a genetic test if patients or their families have certain patterns of disease. Genetic testing is voluntary and the decision about whether to have genetic testing is complex.

A geneticist or genetic counselor can help families think about the benefits and limitations of a particular genetic test. Genetic counselors help individuals and families understand the scientific, emotional, and ethical factors surrounding the decision to have genetic testing and how to deal with the results of those tests.

faqpage.title: Who is at Risk for Retrograde Ejaculation?
fdesc: Retrograde ejaculation can affect men of any age and is most commonly caused by nerve damage, spinal cord injuries, and certain medications. If you are experiencing symptoms of retrograde ejaculation, it is important to consult with a healthcare provider for proper diagnosis and treatment.

faqpage.title: How is genetic information used to treat disease?
fdesc: A person's genetic makeup affects how their body breaks down certain medicines. Genetic testing can examine certain liver enzymes in a person to find out how their body breaks down and removes medicines from the body. Because these liver enzymes are less active in some people, they are less able to break down and get rid of some medicines. This can lead to serious side effects. This type of testing is being used to find the right dose of certain medicines, such as antidepressants that are used to treat some mental illnesses.

faqpage.title: Who is at Risk for an Ectopic Pregnancy?
fdesc: Anyone can be at risk for an ectopic pregnancy, but the risk is higher for women over the age of 35, women who have had a previous ectopic pregnancy, and women with a history of infertility or pelvic inflammatory disease. Women who use assisted reproductive technology may also be at increased risk. It is important to receive prompt medical attention if you suspect you may have an ectopic pregnancy.

faqpage.title: Who is at Risk for Ovulation Problems?
fdesc: Anyone can develop ovulation problems, but the risk is higher for women over the age of 35, women with a history of hormonal imbalances or thyroid disorders, and women with a family history of infertility. Women with PCOS may also be at increased risk. It is important to consult with a healthcare provider if you are experiencing difficulty conceiving or suspect you may have an ovulation problem.

faqpage.title: Who is at Risk for Ovarian Cysts?
fdesc: Anyone can develop ovarian cysts, but the risk is higher for women who are approaching menopause, women with a history of hormonal imbalances or endocrine disorders, and women who have a family history of ovarian cysts. Women who use assisted reproductive technologies may also be at increased risk. It is important to consult with a healthcare provider if you suspect you may have an ovarian cyst.

faqpage.title: Who is at Risk for Menstrual Disorders?
fdesc: Anyone can develop menstrual disorders, but the risk is higher for women over the age of 35, women with a history of hormonal imbalances or thyroid disorders, and women with a family history of menstrual disorders. Women who use assisted reproductive technologies may also be at increased risk. It is important to consult with a healthcare provider if you are experiencing menstrual problems.

faqpage.title: Who is at Risk for Varicoceles?
fdesc: Varicoceles are most common in men between the ages of 15 and 25, but can occur at any age. Men who have a family history of varicoceles or who have had previous testicular surgery are at increased risk for the condition. If you suspect you may have a varicocele, it is important to consult with a healthcare provider for proper diagnosis and treatment.

faqpage.title: What are the common types of chromosomal disorders?
fdesc: Some of the most common chromosomal disorders include Down syndrome, Turner syndrome, and Klinefelter syndrome.

faqpage.title: Is medical management the only option for treating chromosomal disorders?
fdesc: No, medical management is only one of several options for treating chromosomal disorders. The appropriate treatment plan may also include surgery, therapy, and genetic counseling.

faqpage.title: Can therapy help individuals with chromosomal disorders?
fdesc: Yes, therapy, such as physical, occupational, and speech therapy, can help individuals with chromosomal disorders to develop their physical and communication skills.

faqpage.title: Who is at Risk for Erectile Dysfunction?
fdesc: Erectile dysfunction can affect men of any age, but is most common in older men. If you are experiencing symptoms of ED, it is important to consult with a healthcare provider for proper diagnosis and treatment. Early treatment can help improve ED and prevent future complications.

faqpage.title: Who is at Risk for Abnormal Semen Analysis Results?
fdesc: Abnormal semen analysis results can affect men of any age, but are more common in older men and men with underlying health conditions. If you are experiencing symptoms of infertility or are concerned about your semen analysis results, it is important to consult with a healthcare provider for proper diagnosis and treatment.

faqpage.title: What are the potential risks of TESA?
fdesc: As with any medical procedure, TESA does carry a small risk of complications, including infection, bleeding, and pain. Your doctor will discuss any potential risks with you before the procedure.

faqpage.title: Who is a good candidate for micro TESE?
fdesc: Micro TESE is typically recommended for men with non-obstructive azoospermia, where the cause of sperm absence is unknown or related to testicular failure. It may also be recommended for men who have had unsuccessful sperm retrieval with a previous TESE procedure.

faqpage.title: Are there any risks associated with micro TESE?
fdesc: As with any surgical procedure, there is a risk of bleeding, infection, and pain. Additionally, there is a small chance that micro TESE may result in damage to the testicles, leading to decreased sperm production or testicular injury. It is important to discuss the potential risks and benefits with a fertility specialist before undergoing micro TESE.

faqpage.title: What is the thyroid gland?
fdesc: The thyroid is a butterfly-shaped gland located in the neck that produces hormones that regulate metabolism.

faqpage.title: What is hypothyroidism?
fdesc: Hypothyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland does not produce enough hormones, leading to a slowdown of the body's metabolism.

faqpage.title: What are the symptoms of hypothyroidism?
fdesc: Common symptoms of hypothyroidism include fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation, and depression.

faqpage.title: What causes Vitamin D deficiency?
fdesc: Lack of sun exposure: Vitamin D is produced in the body through exposure to sunlight. If you don't get enough sun, you may become deficient in Vitamin D.
Dietary restrictions: Vitamin D is found in limited amounts in food sources, so people who follow a restricted diet or have food allergies may be at risk of deficiency.

faqpage.title: Are there any side effects to Vitamin D supplementation?
fdesc: Yes, there can be side effects associated with Vitamin D supplementation. Although, in most cases, these side effects are mild and temporary. Some of the common side effects include: Nausea and upset stomach,Loss of appetite,Headache,Muscle or bone pain,Weakness or fatigue

faqpage.title: Can a hormonal imbalance cause infertility?
fdesc: Yes, hormonal imbalances can cause infertility by affecting the production and regulation of reproductive hormones.

faqpage.title: What are hormones?
fdesc: Hormones are chemical messengers produced by the endocrine glands that regulate various bodily functions such as growth, metabolism, and reproductive processes.

faqpage.title: How is a hormonal imbalance treated?
fdesc: Treatment for a hormonal imbalance depends on the specific cause and type of hormone involved. Hormonal imbalances can be treated with medication, lifestyle changes, or hormone replacement therapy.

faqpage.title: What are the health consequences of obesity?
fdesc: Obesity can lead to various health problems, including heart disease, stroke, type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, sleep apnea, and certain types of cancer.

faqpage.title: How is obesity treated?
fdesc: Treatment for obesity typically involves a combination of lifestyle changes, such as healthy eating and increased physical activity, and in some cases, medication or bariatric surgery.

faqpage.title: Can diet and exercise help with weight loss?
fdesc: Weight loss supplements and diet pills may help with short-term weight loss, but they are not a long-term solution and can have negative side effects. It is important to discuss any weight loss supplements or pills with a doctor before starting to use them.

faqpage.title: What is an autoimmune disease?
fdesc: An autoimmune disease is a condition in which the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's own healthy tissues, causing inflammation and damage.

faqpage.title: What causes autoimmune diseases?
fdesc: The exact cause of autoimmune diseases is not known, but a combination of genetic, environmental, and lifestyle factors is thought to play a role.

faqpage.title: Can autoimmune diseases be prevented?
fdesc: There is no known way to prevent autoimmune diseases, but early diagnosis and treatment can help reduce the risk of long-term complications and improve quality of life.

faqpage.title: Are autoimmune diseases hereditary?
fdesc: Autoimmune diseases can run in families, suggesting a genetic component, but not all autoimmune diseases are necessarily hereditary.

faqpage.title: What causes diabetes?
fdesc: Type 1 diabetes is caused by the destruction of insulin-producing cells in the pancreas. Type 2 diabetes is caused by the body's inability to effectively use insulin. Risk factors for type 2 diabetes include obesity, family history, and age.

faqpage.title: What are the symptoms of diabetes?
fdesc: Symptoms of diabetes can include increased thirst, frequent urination, blurred vision, and fatigue. In severe cases, it can lead to serious health complications such as heart disease, nerve damage, and kidney disease.

faqpage.title: How is diabetes diagnosed?
fdesc: Diabetes is diagnosed through a combination of a fasting plasma glucose test, an oral glucose tolerance test, or an A1C test.

faqpage.title: How successful is egg freezing?
fdesc: The success rate of egg freezing can vary, but recent advancements in freezing techniques have improved the chances of a successful pregnancy.

faqpage.title: Is egg freezing safe?
fdesc: Egg freezing is generally considered safe, but like any medical procedure, it carries some risks, such as ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, bleeding, and infection.

faqpage.title: How long can eggs be stored?
fdesc: Eggs can be stored for an indefinite amount of time, but the length of storage and quality of the eggs can impact their viability for use in fertility treatment.

faqpage.title: Why would someone choose to freeze their sperm?
fdesc: Sperm freezing is often chosen by men who want to preserve their fertility for personal or medical reasons, such as in preparation for medical treatments that may impact their fertility or as a form of contraception.

faqpage.title: How successful is sperm freezing?
fdesc: The success rate of sperm freezing is high, with a large number of successful pregnancies achieved with thawed sperm

faqpage.title: Is sperm freezing safe?
fdesc: Sperm freezing is generally considered safe, but like any medical procedure, it carries some risks, such as infection.

faqpage.title: How long can sperm be stored?
fdesc: Sperm can be stored for an indefinite amount of time, but the length of storage and quality of the sperm can impact its viability for use in fertility treatment.

faqpage.title: Why freeze embryos?
fdesc: Embryos can be frozen to allow couples to preserve their fertility for later use, such as if they are undergoing cancer treatment or waiting to start a family.

faqpage.title: How long can embryos be frozen?
fdesc: Embryos can be stored for many years and still remain viable for future use.

faqpage.title: What are the success rates of embryo thawing and transfer?
fdesc: The success rates of embryo thawing and transfer can vary, but studies have shown that the success rates are similar to those of fresh embryos. The success of the procedure depends on many factors, including the age of the woman, the quality of the embryos, and the reason for freezing.

faqpage.title: What conditions can Laparoscopy treat?
fdesc: Laparoscopy can be used to treat a variety of conditions, including endometriosis, fibroids, ovarian cysts, and pelvic pain.

faqpage.title: Is Laparoscopy safe?
fdesc: Laparoscopy is generally considered a safe procedure, but like any surgery, there are risks involved such as infection, bleeding, and damage to internal organs. Your doctor will be able to discuss the risks and benefits with you.

faqpage.title: What conditions can Laparoscopy treat?
fdesc: Laparoscopy can be used to treat a variety of conditions, including endometriosis, fibroids, ovarian cysts, and pelvic pain.

faqpage.title: is Hysteroscopy safe?
fdesc: Hysteroscopy is a safe and effective diagnostic procedure that helps doctors diagnose and treat various gynecological conditions. If you have any questions or concerns about this procedure, be sure to talk to your doctor.

faqpage.title: Why is Uterine Septal Resection performed?
fdesc: The procedure is performed to treat uterine malformations, such as a septate uterus, which can cause fertility problems, recurrent miscarriages, or problems during pregnancy.

faqpage.title: What is the recovery time for Uterine Septal Resection?
fdesc: ecovery time can vary, but most patients can return to normal activities within 1-2 weeks.

faqpage.title: Why is USR performed?
fdesc: USR is performed to treat infertility and recurrent pregnancy loss caused by a uterine septum.

faqpage.title: What are the risks and side effects of USR?
fdesc: Like all surgical procedures, USR carries a risk of bleeding, infection, and scarring. Additionally, there may be temporary side effects such as cramping and spotting after the procedure.

faqpage.title: What are the symptoms of uterine fibroids?
fdesc: Common symptoms of uterine fibroids include heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain or pressure, frequent urination, constipation and lower back pain.

faqpage.title: What is the purpose of Myomectomy?
fdesc: The purpose of Myomectomy is to remove uterine fibroids and preserve the uterus, allowing women to have children in the future if they so desire.

faqpage.title: Is Myomectomy a permanent solution for uterine fibroids?
fdesc: Myomectomy can be an effective treatment for uterine fibroids, but it is not a guarantee that they will not grow back. Regular follow-up and monitoring is recommended to ensure the best outcomes.

faqpage.title: Is Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy effective?
fdesc: Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy is generally considered to be an effective treatment for endometrial and dermoid cysts, providing relief from symptoms and reducing the risk of complications. The success of the procedure depends on various factors, including the size and location of the cysts and the overall health of the patient.

faqpage.title: Is Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy safe?
fdesc: Endometrial/Dermoid Cystectomy is a safe and effective treatment option for women with endometrial or dermoid cysts that are causing symptoms or are suspicious on imaging tests.
